content.description: Feathers' easiest climb--good for first leads or soloing. Low angle featured rock for 3 bolts, then walk 15 feet to the base of the tower and climb slightly harder rock to one bolt and anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts on the first face, one bolt and anchors with chains on the final tower.
content.location: Third route from the right on the northside of Feathers.

content.description:
Beta: Follow the obvious wiggling crack between two basalt columns. Use your hands and feet.

Top out options:

Near the top of the crack you will find a nice ledge system to your right with which you can access the anchors for the "Unknown" 10b/c next door.

OR

Follow the crack to the top, and walk around the formation to your right, flipping your rope over the top of the column, to access the anchors for the "Unknown" 10b/c.

Either way, that's your way off.

(Note: This was not in the Sullivan/Yoder book, nor Whitelaw's Weekend Rock so I'm tossing this name out there. I have not checked other books though and would love a fact check if anyone has the Smoot guide, ect...)
content.location: Far right side of the Feathers - North

climbs.name: The Uprising
climbs.fa: Jeff Ball, John Buckley & Kevin Kurtz (1988)

content.description: Fun route.  The best part is the crux (between 2nd and 3rd bolt) which is really the only thing that makes it different from the other climbs around it.
content.location: This route is on the face just to the right of Desert Shield.

content.description:
Overhanging top rope route.  Without using the wall behind it, it feels 5.10b/c. Stemming off the wall behind it make it 5.easy. Both ways of climbing it are fun.

This route is not in the 2019 edition of Sullivan & Yoder's Frenchman Coulee book, however, the route is quite old. The anchor is stacked washers with long chains and TR can be set up by walking around the south side.
content.location: Overhanging route with graffiti at the base. On the opposite side of the pillar of Where the Sidewalk Ends.

content.description: Overhanging incut jugs to a typical section where the patina ends on sloping, less secure holds, then up some broken choss to the anchors.
content.location: North side of the Feathers, way to the left if you are facing south towards the notch.  The furthest left climb on the cliff.

content.description: Decent short climb on the face of a pillar with a small roof between the first and second bolts.
content.location: Just behind the Satan's Pillar formation.

content.description: Bit runout to the 1st bolt.
content.protection: 4 bolts to an anchor at top
content.location: Five climbs to the right of the walkthrough. Just to the right of "porthole" and to the left of "Mandatory Suicide".

content.description: This route ascends the arete and face just to the right of Satan's Little Helper. It is more technical than most Feathers routes with a start on big jugs leading to an airy crux with techy feet.
Great climb, straight forward and just keeps going. Use your feet and avoid the pump.

This is the super chossy double crack system just to the left of the walk-through to the south side with obvious shiny chain anchors. Fun climb but definitely watch out for loose gravel, rocks, and blocks.
content.location: Just left of the walk-through.

content.description: Short & fun--good warm up or beginner route.
content.location: Second to the furthest route to the right on the Feathers northside.

content.description: This crack is known as "The Mirror" on the south side.  Finish on "Shake It Don't Break It" anchors.
content.location: Located directly right of "The Uprising".

content.description: This route was the original route on Satan's Pillar. It was first climbed in 1948 by Gene and Bill Prater. It was retro-bolted by Jim Yoder in 1999 with the first lead of the bolted version by Helen Shull. This is a fun, easy lead to get to the top of the pillar. 25 feet of vertical, big edges leads to broken terrain at the anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts and anchor with rap chains.
content.location: This route starts in the notch on the southwest side of Satan's Pillar.

content.description: fun route, some loose rock on the right side of arete beware
content.location: left of the gap between North & South Feathers

content.description: Easy climb good for soloing. 3 bolts visible from the ground. Climb up to a landing and walk forward toward a second pillar that has one more bolt and a chain anchor.
content.location: This is the slanted pillar to the right of Forty Bucks in the Dark.

climbs.name: Mandatory Suicide
climbs.fa: Mike Hylland, Kevin Pogue, Craig Dodson

content.description: Quality easy route.
content.protection: 4 clips, look for the top anchor on the pillar to the right.
content.location: Route second to the right of the walk-through.

content.description: Moderate route on typical blocky holds. Pretty fun.
content.location: Jesus Saves is located on Satan's Pillar between Blood Blister and Notch Route.

content.description: Short, not worth it.
content.location: Third route to the right of the walk-through.

content.description: Climb the arete where there's plenty of holds. Easier than Satan's Little Helper.
content.location: Left of Satan's Little Helper. Furthest left route on Satan's Pillar.

content.description: Ample holds with five clips makes this a great beginner lead. Low angle, plenty of holds, but surprisingly little choss for how broken the rock looks. Crux is a blanker section around the fourth bolt.
content.protection: 5 bolts or pro to 3", anchor with rap chains.
content.location: The tilted pillar left of Where the Sidewalk Ends. Far right side of the north Feathers.

content.description: Nice & easy route.
content.location: Route furthest to the right on the north Feathers.

content.description: Short, chossy climb. It's most chossy if you start up the left. At the top there are many chalked up X's which you can see from the ground.
content.location: 2nd route on the right inside the alcove. It's on the long wall across from Satan's Pillar.

content.description: A fun arete.  The first bolt is fairly high, but it felt secure.
content.location: On the northern arete of the Medicine Man column (immediately above the gap between the north and south sides).

content.description: The start of the climb is 5.7/8ish, first and second bolts are easy to get to, but a touch up there.  The crux is at the top of the climb at the overhang, but is protected.  After a big mantle at the top, you're done. The rap bolts are a good 15 feet back, bring some long slings if you plan to TR it after lead.  There is chains, but you can downclimb off the back side easy enough
content.location: Climb is located 2 faces left of satan's little helper

content.description: Fun route on an arete featuring solid incut holds and interesting moves for the grade.
content.location: 2 left of Satan's Little Helper on arete.

content.description: crux comes right after 2nd bolt after that its all about pump management.
content.location: to the right of satans wagon.

content.description: high first bolt, good holds though. the crux is a secret of course. Find it on your own
content.location: right of Criminally Insane, not on the Satanic Pillar

content.description: Nice route.
content.location: Fourth route from the right on the northside of Feathers.

content.description: This route wasn't listed in the old guide book and thus I didn't know much about it when I climbed it. Maybe the community can pitch in the details! *Updated, thank you Tiffany Samson for name, grade suggestion, and FA. It is a slight overhang jug/crimp haul. It has one distinctive crux near the end after the last bolt. Hint; going left is easier than direct! 5.9+ if you go left at the bulge and 5.10b if you go up straight.
content.location: Located left of Beckey Route on the same column.

content.description: Steep face climb across from Jesus Saves.
content.location: North side of the Feathers, across from Jesus Saves.
